title: closure properties of regular language
html:
regularity is having finite periodicity

Closure Properties of Regular Languages

Regular languages are a fundamental class of languages in formal language theory. They are closed under various operations, meaning that applying these operations to regular languages results in another regular language. Below are the key closure properties:

1. Union

  • Definition: If L1L_1L1​ and L2L_2L2​ are regular languages, then L1∪L2L_1 \cup L_2L1​∪L2​ is also regular.

  • Proof: Use the construction of a finite automaton (FA) or regular expression for L1∪L2L_1 \cup L_2L1​∪L2​.

  • Example: If L1={an∣n≥0}L_1 = \{a^n \mid n \geq 0\}L1​={an∣n≥0} and L2={bn∣n≥0}L_2 = \{b^n \mid n \geq 0\}L2​={bn∣n≥0}, then L1∪L2L_1 \cup L_2L1​∪L2​ is regular.

2. Intersection

  • Definition: If L1L_1L1​ and L2L_2L2​ are regular languages, then L1∩L2L_1 \cap L_2L1​∩L2​ is also regular.

  • Proof: Use the product construction of finite automata for L1L_1L1​ and L2L_2L2​.

3. Complement

  • Definition: If LLL is a regular language over an alphabet Σ\SigmaΣ, then L‾=Σ∗−L\overline{L} = \Sigma^* - LL=Σ∗−L is also regular.

  • Proof: Swap accepting and non-accepting states in the deterministic finite automaton (DFA) for LLL.

  • Example: If L={an∣n≥0}L = \{a^n \mid n \geq 0\}L={an∣n≥0}, then L‾\overline{L}L includes all strings over Σ={a}\Sigma = \{a\}Σ={a} that are not in LLL.

4. Concatenation

  • Definition: If L1L_1L1​ and L2L_2L2​ are regular languages, then L1⋅L2={xy∣x∈L1,y∈L2}L_1 \cdot L_2 = \{xy \mid x \in L_1, y \in L_2\}L1​⋅L2​={xy∣x∈L1​,y∈L2​} is also regular.

  • Proof: Use the construction of a finite automaton or regular expression for L1⋅L2L_1 \cdot L_2L1​⋅L2​.

  • Example: If L1={an∣n≥0}L_1 = \{a^n \mid n \geq 0\}L1​={an∣n≥0} and L2={bm∣m≥0}L_2 = \{b^m \mid m \geq 0\}L2​={bm∣m≥0}, then L1⋅L2={anbm∣n,m≥0}L_1 \cdot L_2 = \{a^n b^m \mid n, m \geq 0\}L1​⋅L2​={anbm∣n,m≥0} is regular.

5. Kleene Star

  • Definition: If LLL is a regular language, then L∗L^*L∗ (the Kleene star of LLL) is also regular.

  • Proof: Construct a finite automaton or regular expression for L∗L^*L∗.

  • Example: If L={a,b}L = \{a, b\}L={a,b}, then L∗={ϵ,a,b,aa,ab,ba,bb,… }L^* = \{\epsilon, a, b, aa, ab, ba, bb, \dots\}L∗={ϵ,a,b,aa,ab,ba,bb,…} is regular.

6. Reversal

  • Definition: If LLL is a regular language, then LR={wR∣w∈L}L^R = \{w^R \mid w \in L\}LR={wR∣w∈L} (the reversal of LLL) is also regular.

  • Proof: Reverse the transitions of a finite automaton for LLL.

  • Example: If L={anbm∣n,m≥0}L = \{a^n b^m \mid n, m \geq 0\}L={anbm∣n,m≥0}, then LR={bman∣n,m≥0}L^R = \{b^m a^n \mid n, m \geq 0\}LR={bman∣n,m≥0} is regular.

7. Difference

  • Definition: If L1L_1L1​ and L2L_2L2​ are regular languages, then L1−L2L_1 - L_2L1​−L2​ is also regular.

  • Proof: Use the fact that L1−L2=L1∩L2‾L_1 - L_2 = L_1 \cap \overline{L_2}L1​−L2​=L1​∩L2​​, and regular languages are closed under intersection and complement.

  • Example: If L1={anbm∣n,m≥0}L_1 = \{a^n b^m \mid n, m \geq 0\}L1​={anbm∣n,m≥0} and L2={anbn∣n≥0}L_2 = \{a^n b^n \mid n \geq 0\}L2​={anbn∣n≥0}, then L1−L2L_1 - L_2L1​−L2​ is regular.

8. Homomorphism

  • Definition: If LLL is a regular language and hhh is a homomorphism, then h(L)h(L)h(L) is also regular.

  • Proof: Apply the homomorphism to the regular expression or finite automaton for LLL.

  • Example: If L={an∣n≥0}L = \{a^n \mid n \geq 0\}L={an∣n≥0} and h(a)=bh(a) = bh(a)=b, then h(L)={bn∣n≥0}h(L) = \{b^n \mid n \geq 0\}h(L)={bn∣n≥0} is regular.

9. Inverse Homomorphism

  • Definition: If LLL is a regular language and hhh is a homomorphism, then h−1(L)h^{-1}(L)h−1(L) is also regular.

  • Proof: Construct a finite automaton for h−1(L)h^{-1}(L)h−1(L) using the finite automaton for LLL.

  • Example: If L={bn∣n≥0}L = \{b^n \mid n \geq 0\}L={bn∣n≥0} and h(a)=bh(a) = bh(a)=b, then h−1(L)={an∣n≥0}h^{-1}(L) = \{a^n \mid n \geq 0\}h−1(L)={an∣n≥0} is regular.

10. Substitution

  • Definition: If LLL is a regular language and σ\sigmaσ is a substitution that maps each symbol to a regular language, then σ(L)\sigma(L)σ(L) is also regular.

  • Proof: Use the closure properties of regular languages under union, concatenation, and Kleene star.

  • Example: If L={a,b}L = \{a, b\}L={a,b} and σ(a)={an∣n≥0}\sigma(a) = \{a^n \mid n \geq 0\}σ(a)={an∣n≥0}, σ(b)={bm∣m≥0}\sigma(b) = \{b^m \mid m \geq 0\}σ(b)={bm∣m≥0}, then σ(L)\sigma(L)σ(L) is regular.

11. Quotient with Regular Languages

  • Definition: If L1L_1L1​ and L2L_2L2​ are regular languages, then L1/L2={x∣∃y∈L2,xy∈L1}L_1 / L_2 = \{x \mid \exists y \in L_2, xy \in L_1\}L1​/L2​={x∣∃y∈L2​,xy∈L1​} is also regular.

  • Proof: Construct a finite automaton for L1/L2L_1 / L_2L1​/L2​ using the finite automaton for L1L_1L1​.

  • Example: If L1={anbm∣n,m≥0}L_1 = \{a^n b^m \mid n, m \geq 0\}L1​={anbm∣n,m≥0} and L2={bm∣m≥0}L_2 = \{b^m \mid m \geq 0\}L2​={bm∣m≥0}, then L1/L2={an∣n≥0}L_1 / L_2 = \{a^n \mid n \geq 0\}L1​/L2​={an∣n≥0} is regular.

Summary

Regular languages are closed under:

  1. Union

  2. Intersection

  3. Complement

  4. Concatenation

  5. Kleene Star

  6. Reversal

  7. Difference

  8. Homomorphism

  9. Inverse Homomorphism

  10. Substitution

  11. Quotient with Regular Languages

These properties make regular languages a robust and well-studied class in formal language theory.
